Name of the module, theme, or layout Olivero Theme Link to the drupal.org module, theme, or layout https://www.drupal.org/project/olivero This will be the new Drupal 9.1 core theme, so it would not...
Or feel free to open a core issue requesting a new theme for Backdrop, then we can discuss there.
Having said that, I feel that if we did decide to make a new core theme by default (admin or otherwise), I'd want it to be unique to Backdrop and not just a port of an existing Drupal theme.

Yes we're a fork of Drupal, and yes we hope a lot of our audience over the next few years will be people migrating from Drupal, but we are also our own project and I'd like to see us start differentiating ourselves from Drupal in some small ways.

Description of the need A common "Opportunity" listed in Google PageSpeed insights is to "Serve images in next-gen formats." Backdrop does not currently support any next-gen for...

@indigoxela heh... I proposed that webp was put into core of D7 not very long after its release. My suggestion was that webp was pushed as the default image with a fallback to the more stable formats. Needless to say, it never went anywhere. Now that D9 is out, there's talk about them implementing it in some form though I believe it's just to add it as a recognized format, not to add any sort of fallback.

The two reasons I believe webp never took off:
1) Internet Explorer
2) Nobody wanted to implement a push first fallback else method for the browsers that didn't support it at the time.

Had the big web players (wordpress etc) done this from the beginning, I personally believe webp would have become the default image format years ago. Firefox wouldn't have waited until 2019 to add it and Safari is still yet to add it. Chrome currently holds around a 60% market share which is going to grow to about 85%-90% with Edge now being built off Chromium and FF having a rather sad and painful death.

I'll digress ;-)

Oh, not trying to suggest anything persay, just throwing out some thoughts on the matter.

@indigoxela (or others), can you please have a look at my question in https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop/pull/3265/files#r519239098 ?

@Phil Ward Many thanks for providing your feedback.

The main intention of my comment was to encourage people to test the PR on their local.

In Backdrop webp support has good chances to go into 1.18. (January) - it already has a milestone set and an advocate (me). The only culprit is the lack of people testing it.

@indigoxela gotcha, I'll do what I can.

I read through most of the issue queue but didn't quite find the answer to a question I have. Is this going to be designed to convert images to webp on upload through gd, imagemagick etc or will this inclusion simply just allow webp files to be uploaded and served? I'm guessing the former from what I gathered, but some clarification would be nice.

Is this going to be designed to convert images to webp on upload through gd, imagemagick etc or will this inclusion simply just allow webp files to be uploaded and served?

The intention is to provide support for uploading and handling webp in core (with gd). Conversion to webp (set webp as default image output type) is supposed to go to contrib - which is currently blocked by the lack of core webp support, but should be possible after the PR has been merged.

@Phil Ward does this answer your question?

@indigoxela yes, thank you. I kind of gathered that was the direction and hoped it was.

I suppose be thinking about having a way to do a fallback to the "original" file. If it weren't for safari not properly supporting webp, I wouldn't worry about it as much but considering the range of browsers out there, having two versions available to send to those that support it and those that don't will ensure cross compatibility for quite some time. Maybe this has been discussed and I'm unaware. I would be fine honestly if this was contrib. At some point in the future it shouldn't be necessary to cater to supporting vs non-supporting (in theory) and it would leave the site maintainer to determine if they neef backwards compatibility in the meantime.
